parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several farmland management practices are effective for increasing butterfly and moth abundance.
[Statement 2]: Converting to organic farming shows significant benefits for butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 3]: Organic arable farms have greater species richness and abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 4]: The effectiveness of converting to organic farming for butterfly and moth populations varies with landscape context and is more pronounced in intensively managed areas.
[Statement 5]: The benefits of organic farming for butterflies and moths may be stronger in farms managed organically for less than 6 years.
[Statement 6]: Planting nectar flower mixtures and wildflower strips is highly effective for increasing butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 7]: Sown wildflower strips have a higher abundance of all butterflies, generalist butterflies, specialist butterflies, and meadow brown butterflies than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields, and conventional grassland.
[Statement 8]: Wildflower strips have higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths compared to conventional alternatives.
[Statement 9]: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use generally benefits butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 10]: Areas managed with less frequent, reduced, or no chemical inputs have greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 11]: Areas with reduced chemical use have a higher abundance of butterflies and moths.
[Statement 12]: Increasing or maintaining the proportion of natural or semi-natural habitat in the farmed landscape is effective for butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 13]: Farms with greater proportions of semi-natural habitat have higher species richness of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths compared to conventional farmland.
[Statement 14]: Maintaining species-rich, semi-natural grassland shows mixed results for butterfly and moth abundance depending on the management approach.
[Statement 15]: Lightly grazed or annually mown grasslands can have a higher abundance of butterflies compared to areas under intensive farming.
[Statement 16]: The effectiveness of managing semi-natural grassland for butterflies varies by specific management timing and intensity.
[Statement 17]: Planting new hedges increases butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 18]: There is a higher abundance of butterflies, moths, and macro-moths along hedgerows than on beetle banks, grass margins without hedgerows, or field interiors.
[Statement 19]: Undersowing spring cereals with clover shows promise for increasing butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 20]: Spring barley undersown with grasses and legumes has higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than extensively or conventionally managed grassland.
[Statement 21]: Planting wild bird seed or cover mixture provides benefits for butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 22]: Plots sown with wild bird seed mixture have greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies than a wheat crop or extensively managed grassland.
[Statement 23]: Managing vineyards to benefit butterflies and moths shows effectiveness.
[Statement 24]: Grass strips between vine rows and vineyards managed with fewer chemicals have greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than conventionally managed vineyards.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective management practices on farmland for increasing butterfly and moth abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Alternative management strategies to prescribed burning for maintaining open grassland habitats for butterflies include several mowing, cutting, and grazing approaches.
[Statement 2]: Grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years have greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than grasslands cut in full annually.
[Statement 3]: Grasslands that have rotational areas left uncut have greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than grasslands cut in full annually.
[Statement 4]: Rotationally mown grasslands benefitted 27 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.
[Statement 5]: Two heath fritillary populations survived on rotationally mown grasslands while six populations went extinct on unmanaged grasslands.
[Statement 6]: Prairies managed by haying show a higher abundance of prairie specialist butterflies than prairies managed by burning.
[Statement 7]: The abundance of prairie specialist butterflies was higher in the first year after haying than in the second year.
[Statement 8]: Rotational cattle- and sheep-grazed grasslands had greater species richness of butterflies and burnet moths than continuously grazed or patch-burned grassland.
[Statement 9]: Meadows cut once per year have higher species richness of butterflies and moths than meadows cut two or more times per year.
[Statement 10]: Grassland cut once per year in July or September had a greater abundance of butterflies, burnet moths and caterpillars than grassland cut once or twice per year in May or June.
[Statement 11]: One pine barren managed for 13 years by mechanical cutting had a higher abundance of Karner blue butterflies than barrens managed by rotational burning.
[Statement 12]: Managing wetlands or ponds by cutting can prevent succession.
[Statement 13]: Recently cut fens had fewer large copper eggs than uncut fens.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the alternative management strategies to prescribed burning for maintaining open grassland habitats for butterflies?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on documented studies, habitat connectivity provides several benefits for butterfly populations.
[Statement 2]: Restoring connectivity between habitat patches increased the abundance of multiple butterfly species, including Karner blue, high brown fritillary, small pearl-bordered fritillary, marsh fritillary, and regal fritillary.
[Statement 3]: Studies found that common buckeye and variegated fritillary butterflies were more likely to move between connected than unconnected habitat patches.
[Statement 4]: Grassland strips providing nectar or shelter were more likely to be used by butterfly species than strips with no resources.
[Statement 5]: For population retention, low quality habitat patches that were well connected were more likely to retain Alcon large blue populations than less well connected patches.
[Statement 6]: Connectivity did not affect occupancy of high quality patches by Alcon large blue populations.
[Statement 7]: Connectivity influenced colonization behavior, as common buckeye butterflies were more likely to colonize farther away habitat patches when released on corridors of suitable habitat compared to unsuitable habitat.
[Statement 8]: The effect of corridor suitability on the colonization behavior of common buckeye butterflies was not observed when the butterflies were released close to habitat patches.
[Statement 9]: One study found that well connected cleared patches within woodland had similar species richness of butterflies to isolated cleared patches.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented benefits of retaining or restoring habitat connectivity for butterfly populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In UK agricultural settings, several grassland management techniques are beneficial for increasing butterfly and moth abundance.
[Statement 2]: Reducing management intensity on permanent grasslands shows strong benefits for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 3]: Less intensively managed grasslands have higher species richness of butterflies and moths than conventionally managed grasslands.
[Statement 4]: Low-input or unfertilized, ungrazed grassland managed with a single cut has higher species richness of butterflies and moths compared to intensively managed grassland.
[Statement 5]: Low-input or unfertilized, ungrazed grassland managed with a single cut has a higher abundance of butterflies and moths compared to intensively managed grassland.
[Statement 6]: Rotational mowing techniques provide significant advantages for butterflies.
[Statement 7]: Grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years have greater species richness and diversity of butterflies than grasslands cut in full once per year.
[Statement 8]: A higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths was found in grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years compared to grasslands cut in full once or twice per year.
[Statement 9]: A higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths was found in grasslands managed by leaving rotational areas uncut on each mow compared to grasslands cut in full once or twice per year.
[Statement 10]: The majority of butterfly species studied preferred meadows which were half mown in June and August over meadows cut in full twice per year.
[Statement 11]: Converting to organic farming demonstrates benefits for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 12]: Organic arable farms have greater species richness and abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 13]: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use generally shows positive effects for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 14]: Farms managed with less frequent, reduced or no chemical input have greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 15]: Restoring arable land to permanent grassland provides benefits for moths and butterflies.
[Statement 16]: Restored grasslands have a higher abundance of moths than conventional grassland.
[Statement 17]: Restored grasslands established by sowing grasses, legumes and other non-woody, broadleaved plants have a higher species richness of butterflies compared to grass-only mixes.
[Statement 18]: Agri-environment schemes demonstrate effectiveness for increasing butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 19]: The species richness or diversity of butterflies and moths on grassland managed under agri-environment schemes is higher than on conventional fields or farms.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which grassland management techniques in UK agricultural settings are most beneficial for increasing butterfly and moth abundance?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the benefits for butterflies and moths of reducing or eliminating chemical inputs on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Reducing or eliminating chemical inputs on farmland provides several documented benefits for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 2]: Areas not sprayed with herbicides such as glyphosate and fluazifop-P-butyl have greater species richness of butterflies compared to sprayed areas.
[Statement 3]: Areas not sprayed with herbicides such as glyphosate and fluazifop-P-butyl have a higher total abundance of butterflies compared to sprayed areas.
[Statement 4]: Plants not sprayed with insecticides like Karate Zeon have a higher abundance of moth eggs and caterpillars.
[Statement 5]: A general reduction of fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use results in greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths compared to areas with conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 6]: A general reduction of fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use results in a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths compared to areas with conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 7]: The benefits of reducing chemical inputs include increases in adult butterflies, adult moths, and caterpillars.
[Statement 8]: Unfertilized grassland shows greater species richness of specialist moths compared to fertilized grassland.
[Statement 9]: Organic arable farms have greater species richness of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 10]: Organic arable farms have a greater abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 11]: The abundance of butterflies increases with time since farms converted to organic management.
[Statement 12]: When farms convert to organic management, the species richness of large moths can increase within 4 years.
[Statement 13]: When farms convert to organic management, the total abundance of large moths can increase within 4 years.
[Statement 14]: Unsprayed headlands in fields have greater species richness of butterflies and caterpillars than headlands sprayed with herbicide and insecticide.
[Statement 15]: Unsprayed headlands in fields have a greater abundance of butterflies and caterpillars than headlands sprayed with herbicide and insecticide.
[Statement 16]: Butterflies spend more time feeding in unsprayed headlands compared to sprayed areas.
[Statement 17]: Butterflies spend more time interacting in unsprayed headlands compared to sprayed areas.

[Statement 1]: Tree thinning within forests, when combined with mulching or nearby felling, increased butterfly species richness and abundance one to four years after management.
[Statement 2]: Selectively logged forests had a higher abundance of moth caterpillars compared to clearcut forests.
[Statement 3]: Selectively logged forests had a similar or higher abundance of butterflies compared to primary forest.
[Statement 4]: Forests managed by thinning had higher moth species richness than those managed by patch-cutting or clearcutting.
[Statement 5]: Scalloped woodland edges had a higher abundance of brown hairstreak eggs than straight edges.
[Statement 6]: Felling 5-meter-wide woodland edges with thinning of adjacent forest increased butterfly and moth species richness.
[Statement 7]: Felling 5-meter-wide woodland edges with thinning of adjacent forest increased specialist butterfly abundance.
[Statement 8]: Cork oak woodlands with more recent mechanical clearance of vegetation had greater butterfly species richness and abundance than those cleared less frequently.
[Statement 9]: Pearl-bordered fritillary populations were more likely to persist in woodlands with larger areas of young plantations than in mature woodland.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are some evidence-based alternatives to prescribed burning for managing disturbance in forests to benefit butterflies?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence regarding the effectiveness of agri-environment schemes for butterfly and moth conservation across Europe shows mixed but generally positive results.
[Statement 2]: Thirty-two studies have evaluated the effects of paying farmers to cover the costs of conservation measures on butterflies and moths.
[Statement 3]: The majority of studies evaluating agri-environment schemes for butterflies and moths were conducted in the UK, Switzerland, and Finland.
[Statement 4]: Single studies evaluating agri-environment schemes for butterflies and moths have been conducted in Sweden, Czech Republic, USA, and Germany.
[Statement 5]: Twelve of fifteen studies found that butterflies and moths on land managed under agri-environment schemes had higher species richness or diversity than on conventional fields or farms.
[Statement 6]: Three studies found that species richness for butterflies and moths was similar on land managed under agri-environment schemes compared to conventional fields or farms.
[Statement 7]: One study in Finland found that species richness was lower on agri-environment scheme grassland compared to abandoned, unmanaged grassland.
[Statement 8]: Seventeen of nineteen studies found that the abundance of butterflies and moths on farms managed under agri-environment schemes was higher than on conventional farms.
[Statement 9]: Three of four studies found higher butterfly abundance on farms or in landscapes with higher proportions of land under agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 10]: Studies in Finland and the Czech Republic found that grassland managed under agri-environment schemes had lower butterfly and moth abundance compared to unmanaged grassland.
[Statement 11]: Specific interventions within agri-environment schemes show varying effectiveness for butterfly and moth conservation.
[Statement 12]: For wildflower strips, eight of thirteen studies found higher species richness of butterflies and moths compared to conventional margins.
[Statement 13]: Ten studies found that wildflower strips had a higher abundance of butterflies and moths compared to conventional margins.
[Statement 14]: Reducing management intensity on permanent grasslands showed positive effects for species richness of butterflies and moths in six of ten studies.
[Statement 15]: Three of four studies showed higher butterfly abundance when management intensity on permanent grasslands was reduced.
[Statement 16]: Set-aside areas demonstrated benefits for the species richness of butterflies and moths in three of four studies.
[Statement 17]: Set-aside areas demonstrated benefits for the abundance of butterflies and moths in two of five studies.
[Statement 18]: Rotational mowing proved effective, with three of four studies showing greater species richness of butterflies and moths.
[Statement 19]: Positive abundance effects for butterflies and moths from rotational mowing were reported in multiple studies.
[Statement 20]: The evidence base for the effectiveness of agri-environment schemes on butterflies and moths is strongest for the UK and Switzerland.
[Statement 21]: Fewer studies on the effectiveness of agri-environment schemes on butterflies and moths exist from other European countries, indicating geographic gaps in the research.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of the evidence regarding the effectiveness of agri-environment schemes for butterfly and moth conservation across Europe?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two main management actions for traditional orchards and vineyards in the USA and Germany have been studied for their effects on butterflies and moths.
[Statement 2]: For traditional orchards, two studies were conducted, one in the USA and one in Germany, evaluating the effects of maintaining traditional orchards on butterflies and moths.
[Statement 3]: A German study found that managed orchards had similar community composition and species richness of butterflies and burnet moths compared to abandoned orchards.
[Statement 4]: A German study found that managed orchards had a lower abundance of butterflies and burnet moths compared to abandoned orchards.
[Statement 5]: A USA study found that an unmanaged and partially managed orchard had greater species richness and diversity of leaf-eating arthropods, including caterpillars, than a commercially managed orchard.
[Statement 6]: For vineyards, two studies were conducted, one in the USA and one in Spain, evaluating the effects of managing vineyards to benefit butterflies and moths.
[Statement 7]: A USA study on vineyards found that grass strips between vine rows had greater species richness of butterflies than the vine rows themselves.
[Statement 8]: A USA study on vineyards found that vineyards managed to encourage native plants with rare insecticide use had greater butterfly abundance than conventionally managed vineyards.
[Statement 9]: A study in Spain found that vineyards managed with fewer chemicals had greater butterfly species richness than conventionally managed vineyards.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What management actions for traditional orchards and vineyards in the USA and Germany have been studied for their effects on butterflies and moths?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In European grasslands, several grazing management strategies show beneficial effects for butterfly species richness.
[Statement 2]: Reducing grazing intensity through lower stocking density appears to be a most beneficial strategy for butterflies.
[Statement 3]: Grasslands grazed with lower stocking densities of sheep, cattle or mixed livestock had greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths than grasslands grazed at higher stocking densities.
[Statement 4]: The seasonal removal of livestock during critical periods benefits butterflies.
[Statement 5]: Grasslands where cattle were removed in summer had greater species richness of butterflies than grasslands grazed throughout the summer.
[Statement 6]: Rotational grazing shows promise for butterfly conservation.
[Statement 7]: Rotational cattle- and sheep-grazed grasslands had a greater species richness of butterflies and burnet moths than continuously grazed or patch-burned grassland.
[Statement 8]: Low-input management approaches that reduce overall management intensity consistently benefit butterfly communities.
[Statement 9]: Less intensively managed grasslands had a higher species richness of butterflies and moths than conventionally managed grasslands.
[Statement 10]: Avoiding intensive management of grasslands appears crucial for butterflies.
[Statement 11]: Grasslands managed with more intensive grazing had a lower abundance of all adult butterflies, adult burnet moths, and species-specific butterflies than ungrazed, lightly or moderately grazed grasslands.
[Statement 12]: While ceasing grazing entirely can benefit some butterfly species, the results are mixed depending on the timing of the cessation.
[Statement 13]: Butterfly density was higher in grasslands where grazing ceased 2-9 years ago than in grasslands abandoned for more than 10 years or in grasslands that are currently grazed.
[Statement 14]: Maintaining traditional semi-natural grassland management through light grazing or annual mowing supports butterfly diversity.
[Statement 15]: Traditional semi-natural grassland management systems have higher butterfly species richness compared to intensively managed grassland.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In European grasslands, which grazing management strategies appear most beneficial for butterfly species richness?
_claude-sonnet-4__Over what timeframes have butterfly communities been observed to respond to grassland management changes like abandonment or restoration?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Butterfly communities have been observed to respond to grassland management changes across various timeframes ranging from months to decades.
[Statement 2]: Following grassland abandonment from grazing, studies found butterfly community responses occurring within 2 to 9 years.
[Statement 3]: One study showed butterfly density was higher in grasslands where grazing ceased 2-9 years ago than in grasslands abandoned for more than 10 years.
[Statement 4]: For grasslands abandoned for more than 5 to 20 years, results for butterfly species richness and abundance varied depending on the specific timeframe of abandonment.
[Statement 5]: After mowing of grasslands ceased, butterfly community responses were documented from as early as 1 to 3 years to over 25 years.
[Statement 6]: Studies showed grasslands abandoned from mowing for 1 to 6 years had increased woodland and hedgerow butterflies.
[Statement 7]: Studies showed grasslands abandoned from mowing for 1 to 6 years had decreased grassland butterfly species.
[Statement 8]: One study found heath fritillary abundance was similar in grasslands abandoned from mowing for around 6 years compared to annually mown grasslands.
[Statement 9]: Grasslands abandoned from mowing for more than 25 years had a lower abundance of heath fritillary butterflies.
[Statement 10]: For grassland restoration from arable land, butterfly communities developed over a period of 10 years after establishment.
[Statement 11]: Over a 10-year period, butterfly communities on restored grasslands became increasingly similar to communities in existing high-quality grasslands.
[Statement 12]: Studies showed butterfly species richness was higher on grasslands created less than 10 years ago than on grasslands created more than 20 years ago.
[Statement 13]: In prairie restoration, one study found a greater abundance of Fender's blue butterfly eggs in prairies restored 5 to 10 years ago compared to prairies restored 1 to 2 years ago.
[Statement 14]: A controlled study spanning 6 years showed that after abandonment from both grazing and mowing, butterfly communities became dominated by generalist species.
[Statement 15]: A controlled study spanning 6 years showed that after abandonment from both grazing and mowing, butterfly communities became dominated by species with fewer generations per year.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence say about actions to mitigate threats to butterflies and moths from residential and commercial development?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence shows several actions that can mitigate development threats to butterflies and moths.
[Statement 2]: Protecting greenfield sites or undeveloped land in urban areas has been shown to benefit butterflies.
[Statement 3]: Two studies found that protected native forest and grassland in urban areas had higher species richness of butterflies than urban parks or non-native plantations.
[Statement 4]: Legal habitat protection shows mixed but generally positive results.
[Statement 5]: Ten studies found that legally protected sites as National Nature Reserves or Sites of Special Scientific Interest had higher abundance of various butterfly species than unprotected sites.
[Statement 6]: The results of legal habitat protection varied by species and protection type.
[Statement 7]: Ecological compensation for developments shows promise.
[Statement 8]: Two studies reported that translocated butterfly populations from development sites to compensatory habitat can increase in number over time.
[Statement 9]: Compensatory habitat can be successfully utilized by target butterfly species.
[Statement 10]: Establishing green infrastructure in urban areas has been evaluated in one study.
[Statement 11]: One study found that green roofs had lower butterfly richness and abundance than urban parks.
[Statement 12]: Older green roofs with more nectar plant species in larger areas supported higher butterfly abundance.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found that evaluated the effectiveness of requiring Environmental Impact Assessments for planning applications.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found that evaluated the effectiveness of designing road routes to maximize habitat block size.

[Statement 1]: Several actions can improve habitats for butterflies and moths in post-industrial landscapes.
[Statement 2]: Leaving mining sites to restore naturally provides better butterfly and moth habitat than technical restoration.
[Statement 3]: Unflattened spoil heaps have higher species richness of moths than flattened spoil heaps.
[Statement 4]: Restored peat bogs after mining support similar densities and caterpillar sizes of Fred the thread moth compared to undisturbed bogs.
[Statement 5]: Restored moorland has moth communities more similar to established heather moorland than degraded moorland.
[Statement 6]: Silver-studded blue butterfly populations released into sites managed for heathland restoration increased in abundance over 11 years.
[Statement 7]: Silver-studded blue butterfly populations released into sites managed for heathland restoration expanded their range beyond the initial release area.
[Statement 8]: Semi-natural grasslands restored by scrub clearance and reintroduction of grazing or mowing can provide habitat for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 9]: Restored semi-natural grasslands have different butterfly communities compared to existing species-rich grasslands.
[Statement 10]: Some butterfly species show higher abundance on restored grasslands.
[Statement 11]: The density of blue-spot hairstreak eggs is higher in grasslands restored by scrub cutting than in unrestored or continuously managed grasslands.
[Statement 12]: Managing woodland edges for maximum habitat heterogeneity by felling 5-meter-wide edges and thinning adjacent forest increases species richness of butterflies and diurnal moths.
[Statement 13]: Managing woodland edges for maximum habitat heterogeneity by felling 5-meter-wide edges and thinning adjacent forest increases the abundance of specialist butterflies two years after management.
[Statement 14]: Scalloped woodland edges have a higher abundance of brown hairstreak eggs than straight woodland edges.
[Statement 15]: Green roofs have lower butterfly abundance and species richness than urban parks.
[Statement 16]: Butterfly abundance is higher on older green roofs with more nectar plant species in larger areas.
[Statement 17]: Altered mowing regimes significantly benefit butterflies and moths.
[Statement 18]: Less frequently mown or unmown urban greenspaces have higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths than frequently mown areas.
[Statement 19]: Road verges mown less frequently or later in summer have fewer traffic-killed butterflies.
[Statement 20]: Restored roadside prairies and verges sown with native wildflowers and butterfly larval food plants have higher species richness and abundance than verges dominated by non-native vegetation.
[Statement 21]: Wide road verges have higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than narrow road verges.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In post-industrial landscapes, what actions can improve habitats for butterflies and moths?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Unsprayed headlands in UK arable fields had greater species richness of butterflies than headlands sprayed with herbicide and insecticide.
[Statement 2]: Unsprayed headlands in the UK had a greater abundance of butterflies and caterpillars than sprayed headlands.
[Statement 3]: Large white, small white, and green-veined white butterflies spent more time in unsprayed UK arable headlands than in adjacent hedgerows.
[Statement 4]: Large white, small white, and green-veined white butterflies spent more time feeding and interacting in unsprayed headlands.
[Statement 5]: UK studies found that 2-meter grass margins had greater species richness of butterflies than cropped field edges.
[Statement 6]: Grass margins in the UK had a higher abundance of butterflies than cropped field edges.
[Statement 7]: Wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had greater species richness of habitat-sensitive butterflies, macro-moths, and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins.
[Statement 8]: Wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a higher abundance of habitat-sensitive butterflies, macro-moths, and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins.
[Statement 9]: UK farms managed under agri-environment schemes, including uncropped cultivated margins, had a higher abundance of butterflies and micro-moths compared to conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 10]: Fields with wider margins between crops had higher butterfly species richness in one of two years.
[Statement 11]: A UK study found that margins next to water bodies managed with restrictions on fertilizer and pesticide use had a greater abundance of moths than conventionally managed margins.
[Statement 12]: Uncultivated margins in the UK had a higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than cereal fields or cropped field edges.
[Statement 13]: Uncultivated margins which were not cut, or only cut in spring and autumn, had a higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than margins cut in summer.
[Statement 14]: Wider uncultivated margins had a higher abundance of butterflies than conventional margins.
[Statement 15]: UK studies reported that heath fritillary populations survived on rotationally mown grasslands while populations went extinct on unmanaged grasslands.
[Statement 16]: A European review reported that rotationally mowing grassland benefitted 27 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Beyond sowing wildflower mixes, what alternative management practices for field margins and headlands have been shown to benefit butterfly populations on UK farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence shows specific timeframes for butterfly and moth population responses to woodland coppicing and clearing.
[Statement 2]: For woodland coppicing, butterfly abundance was higher in woodland coppiced two, two-four, five-seven or 12-15 years ago compared to woodland coppiced 5-11 or greater than 15 years ago.
[Statement 3]: Species richness of butterflies was greater in woodland coppiced two years ago than woodland coppiced greater than 15 years ago.
[Statement 4]: Pearl-bordered fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary populations were more likely to persist for up to 20 years in coppiced woodland than in mature conifer woodland.
[Statement 5]: For forest clearing, the abundance of butterflies declined over the first three years after clearing.
[Statement 6]: Patches cleared 2-4 years ago had greater abundance of heath fritillary than patches cleared 7-11 years ago or patches in their first year after clearance.
[Statement 7]: Species richness of butterflies declined over the first three years after clearing.
[Statement 8]: Pearl-bordered fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary populations were more likely to persist for up to 20 years in woodlands with larger areas of young plantations or coppicing than in mature woodland.
[Statement 9]: In naturally regenerating forests, butterfly abundance and species richness was highest 12-25 years after felling.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence show about the timeframe for butterfly and moth population response to woodland coppicing or clearing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternative actions to field margins can increase habitat heterogeneity within agricultural fields for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 2]: Planting more than one crop per field, also known as intercropping, was evaluated in Malaysia.
[Statement 3]: A study in Malaysia showed that intercropping resulted in no difference in butterfly species richness, community composition, or abundance when compared to single-crop fields.
[Statement 4]: Increasing crop diversity across a farm or farmed landscape showed similar species richness of butterflies between farms with greater versus fewer habitat or crop types in a study in Switzerland.
[Statement 5]: Reducing field size or maintaining small fields demonstrated positive effects for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 6]: Studies in Sweden, Czech Republic, Poland, and Switzerland showed that smaller fields had a higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found that smaller fields had higher species richness of butterflies and moths compared to larger fields.
[Statement 8]: Creating beetle banks within arable fields showed mixed results in UK studies.
[Statement 9]: Beetle banks had a similar abundance of caterpillars to field margins and crop fields.
[Statement 10]: Beetle banks had lower butterfly abundance and species richness compared to hedgerows.
[Statement 11]: Leaving uncropped, cultivated margins or plots within fields showed varied effects in UK and Switzerland studies.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found higher butterfly abundance under agri-environment schemes that included uncropped, cultivated margins.
[Statement 13]: Other studies found that farms with uncropped margins had similar species richness of butterflies to conventional farms.
[Statement 14]: Planting wild bird seed or a cover mixture demonstrated positive effects for butterflies in UK studies.
[Statement 15]: Plots planted with wild bird seed or a cover mixture had greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies compared to wheat crops and grassland.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Besides planting field margins, what are some alternative actions to increase habitat heterogeneity within agricultural fields for butterflies and moths?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In US prairies, different management techniques show varying effects on butterfly abundance.
[Statement 2]: Prescribed burning shows mixed effects on butterfly abundance depending on its timing and implementation.
[Statement 3]: The total abundance of prairie specialist, grassland, and all butterflies was higher on prairies burned more than one year ago than on prairies burned more recently under rotational burning management.
[Statement 4]: Two prairie specialist butterflies, the regal fritillary and arogos skipper, were less abundant in prairies managed by burning than in prairies managed by haying.
[Statement 5]: The abundance of generalist and migrant butterfly species was higher in burned prairies than in hayed prairies.
[Statement 6]: Leaving unburned patches during prescribed burning improved outcomes for specialist butterflies.
[Statement 7]: Six out of nine specialist butterfly species were more abundant in areas where unburned patches were left during prescribed burning.
[Statement 8]: Prairies managed by haying had a higher abundance of prairie specialist butterflies than prairies managed by burning.
[Statement 9]: Prairies managed by haying had a lower abundance of generalist and migrant butterflies than prairies managed by burning.
[Statement 10]: The abundance of prairie specialist butterflies was higher in the first year after haying than in the second year.
[Statement 11]: Grasslands with more intensive grazing had a lower abundance of adult butterflies than ungrazed or lightly to moderately grazed grasslands.
[Statement 12]: Grasslands managed with grazing in addition to rotational burning had a lower abundance of adult butterflies than rotationally burned grasslands with only occasional light grazing.
[Statement 13]: Rotational grazing showed better outcomes for butterfly abundance than continuous grazing.
[Statement 14]: Rotational cattle-grazed pastures had a higher abundance of butterflies than constantly grazed pastures, but only at a high stocking density, not a low one.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In US prairies, how do different management techniques like grazing, mowing (haying), and prescribed burning compare in their effects on butterfly abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several habitat creation options within European agri-environment schemes consistently show positive effects on butterfly and moth abundance.
[Statement 2]: Nectar flower mixture or wildflower strips are the most consistently effective options for increasing butterfly and moth abundance.
[Statement 3]: Sown wildflower strips had a higher abundance of all butterflies, generalist butterflies, specialist butterflies, and meadow brown butterflies than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields, cropped margins, conventional grassland, or extensively managed meadows.
[Statement 4]: Field margins sown with wildflowers had a higher abundance of butterflies than grass-only field margins.
[Statement 5]: Agri-environment schemes in general show strong positive effects on butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 6]: The abundance of butterflies and moths overall was higher in woodland, grassland, field margins, wildflower strips, or whole farms managed under agri-environment schemes than in unmanaged woodland or conventional fields or farms.
[Statement 7]: The abundance of specific butterfly and moth species was higher in areas managed under agri-environment schemes than in unmanaged woodland or conventional fields or farms.
[Statement 8]: Grass buffer strips or margins around fields show variable but generally positive results for increasing butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 9]: Grass margins had a higher abundance of butterflies than cropped field edges.
[Statement 10]: Wider grass margins (up to 6m wide) had a higher abundance of habitat-sensitive butterflies, macro-moths, and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins.
[Statement 11]: Floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips had a higher abundance of butterflies than standard grass margins.
[Statement 12]: Hedgerow management and creation supports butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 13]: The abundance of butterflies, moths, macro-moths, and gatekeepers was higher along hedgerows than on beetle banks, grass margins without hedgerows, in field interiors, or 5-10 metres away from hedgerows.
[Statement 14]: Hedgerows cut once every 2-3 years had a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, moth caterpillars, and pupae than hedgerows cut to the same size every winter.
[Statement 15]: Hedgerows cut in autumn had a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, moth caterpillars, and pupae than hedgerows cut to the same size every winter.
[Statement 16]: Hedgerows cut to allow incremental growth had a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, moth caterpillars, and pupae than hedgerows cut to the same size every winter.
[Statement 17]: The abundance of butterflies and moths was lower in uncultivated margins than in margins sown with grasses or wildflowers.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Within European agri-environment schemes, which habitat creation options are most consistently shown to increase butterfly and moth abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence for managing perennial crop systems for butterfly and moth conservation shows mixed but generally positive results across different management approaches.
[Statement 2]: In vineyards, studies from the USA and Spain found that grass strips between vine rows had greater species richness of butterflies than vine rows themselves.
[Statement 3]: Vineyards managed with fewer chemicals had greater species richness of butterflies than conventionally managed vineyards.
[Statement 4]: One study showed a greater abundance of butterflies in vineyards managed to encourage native plants where insecticide was rarely used.
[Statement 5]: Three studies from Mexico and Puerto Rico demonstrated that shaded coffee plantations had higher species richness of fruit-eating butterflies and caterpillars compared to sun-grown monoculture coffee plantations.
[Statement 6]: Shade-grown coffee plantations showed a greater abundance of caterpillars than sun-grown plantations.
[Statement 7]: In orchards, studies from Germany and the USA showed that managed orchards had similar species richness of butterflies and burnet moths to abandoned orchards.
[Statement 8]: Managed orchards had a lower abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than abandoned orchards.
[Statement 9]: Unmanaged and partially managed orchards had greater species richness and diversity of leaf-eating arthropods, including caterpillars, than commercially managed orchards.
[Statement 10]: Eleven studies across Europe, USA, Mexico and Switzerland found that orchards, vineyards, and coffee plantations managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer input had greater species richness of adult butterflies, moths, and caterpillars than areas with conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 11]: Eleven studies across Europe, USA, Mexico and Switzerland found that orchards, vineyards, and coffee plantations managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer input had higher abundance of adult butterflies, moths, and caterpillars than areas with conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 12]: Seven of eleven studies on organic farming conversion found organic farms had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 13]: The effectiveness of organic farming conversion for butterfly and moth conservation varied by landscape context.
[Statement 14]: The effectiveness of organic farming conversion for butterfly and moth conservation varied by the time since conversion to organic farming.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for the effectiveness of managing perennial crop systems such as orchards, vineyards, and coffee plantations for butterfly and moth conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can be taken to manage agricultural field boundaries to improve their value for butterfly and moth conservation.
[Statement 2]: Grass buffer strips or margins can be planted around arable or pasture fields.
[Statement 3]: Wider grass margins, up to 6 meters wide, had greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies, macro-moths, and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins.
[Statement 4]: Floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips had a higher abundance of butterflies than standard grass margins.
[Statement 5]: Uncropped arable field margins can be sown with native wild flower seed mixes.
[Statement 6]: Uncropped arable field margins sown with native wild flower seed mixes support higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees than cropped field edges, grassy margins or naturally regenerated uncropped margins.
[Statement 7]: Nectar flower mixture or wildflower strips can be planted to support butterfly and moth conservation.
[Statement 8]: Sown wildflower strips had higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields or conventional grassland.
[Statement 9]: New hedges can be planted to manage agricultural field boundaries for conservation.
[Statement 10]: Established hedgerows had higher species richness of butterflies and macro-moths than crops or pasture.
[Statement 11]: The abundance of butterflies, moths, and macro-moths was higher along hedgerows than on beetle banks, grass margins without hedgerows, or in field interiors.
[Statement 12]: Field size can be reduced or small fields can be maintained to support butterfly and moth conservation.
[Statement 13]: Landscapes with smaller fields had a higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than areas with larger fields.
[Statement 14]: Landscapes with smaller fields had higher species richness of butterflies and burnet moths.
[Statement 15]: For rice cultivation, rice field banks can be managed by keeping the banks unmown and herbicide-free.
[Statement 16]: Unmown and herbicide-free rice field banks had greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies than banks which were mown or sprayed with herbicide.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken to manage agricultural field boundaries to improve their value for butterfly and moth conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several effective actions can be taken along transportation and service corridors to benefit butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 2]: Stopping the use of herbicides on pavements and road verges has been shown to increase both species richness and abundance of butterflies.
[Statement 3]: Restored roadside prairies where herbicide application was restricted have greater butterfly diversity than areas with unrestricted herbicide use.
[Statement 4]: Butterflies experience a lower mortality risk in areas where herbicide application is restricted.
[Statement 5]: Altering mowing regimes on road verges is highly beneficial for butterflies and moths.
[Statement 6]: Less frequently mown or unmown areas support higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths compared to frequently mown areas.
[Statement 7]: Road verges mown less frequently or later in summer have fewer dead butterflies killed by traffic.
[Statement 8]: Restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along road and railway verges significantly enhances butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 9]: Restored roadside prairies and verges sown with native wildflowers or more butterfly larval food plants support higher species richness and abundance than areas dominated by non-native vegetation.
[Statement 10]: Managing land under power lines specifically for butterflies and moths through mechanical cutting has proven effective.
[Statement 11]: Managed areas under power lines show higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than unmanaged land.
[Statement 12]: Butterfly abundance under power lines is highest 2-4 years after scrub and trees are cleared.
[Statement 13]: Retaining connectivity between habitat patches helps maintain butterfly populations.
[Statement 14]: Well-connected low quality habitat patches are more likely to retain butterfly populations than isolated patches.
[Statement 15]: Corridor management strategies collectively create linear habitats that support butterfly and moth conservation while maintaining infrastructure functionality.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken along transportation and service corridors to benefit butterfly and moth populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Reducing or ceasing pesticide and fertilizer use has positive effects on butterfly and moth diversity and abundance.
[Statement 2]: Areas managed with less frequent, reduced, or no pesticide, herbicide, fertilizer, or chemical input had greater species richness of adult butterflies, moths, and caterpillars than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications.
[Statement 3]: Areas managed with reduced or no chemical input had a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths than conventionally treated areas.
[Statement 4]: Unfertilized grassland had greater species richness of specialist moths compared to fertilized grassland.
[Statement 5]: Restricting specific pesticides shows benefits for butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 6]: Arable field margins and rice field banks not sprayed with the herbicide glyphosate had greater species richness and higher total abundance of butterflies than areas sprayed once per year.
[Statement 7]: White campion plants not sprayed with insecticide had a higher abundance of lychnis moth eggs and caterpillars than plants treated with a specific insecticide.
[Statement 8]: Converting to organic farming demonstrates significant positive effects for butterfly and moth populations.
[Statement 9]: Organic arable farms had greater species richness of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 10]: Organic farms had a greater abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventional farms.
[Statement 11]: Butterfly abundance on organic farms increased with the time since conversion to organic management.
[Statement 12]: Unsprayed headlands in arable fields had greater species richness and abundance of butterflies and caterpillars than headlands sprayed with herbicide and insecticide.
[Statement 13]: Margins next to water bodies managed with restrictions on fertilizer and pesticide use had a greater abundance of moths than conventionally managed margins.
[Statement 14]: Less intensively managed grasslands with reduced chemical application had higher species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths than conventionally managed grasslands.
[Statement 15]: Less intensive management of grasslands offers particular benefits for specialist butterfly and moth species and species of conservation concern.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the effects of reducing or ceasing pesticide and fertiliser use on butterfly and moth diversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The main alternatives to grazing for maintaining open grassland habitats include mowing, prescribed burning, and cessation of management.
[Statement 2]: Rotational mowing showed positive effects on butterfly communities.
[Statement 3]: Grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years had greater species richness and diversity of butterflies than grasslands cut in full once per year.
[Statement 4]: Grasslands managed by mowing parts of a site at different times while leaving some areas uncut had greater species richness and diversity of butterflies than grasslands cut in full once per year.
[Statement 5]: Rotationally mown grasslands had a higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths compared to grasslands cut in full once or twice per year.
[Statement 6]: Rotational mowing benefitted 27 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.
[Statement 7]: Reducing cutting frequency generally benefited butterflies.
[Statement 8]: Meadows cut once per year had higher species richness of butterflies and moths than meadows cut two or more times per year.
[Statement 9]: Meadows cut occasionally or once per year had a higher abundance of butterflies than intensively mown grasslands.
[Statement 10]: Delaying cutting dates showed variable effects on butterfly communities.
[Statement 11]: Grassland cut once per year in July or September had a greater abundance of butterflies, burnet moths and caterpillars than grassland cut in May or June, though the effects varied by year.
[Statement 12]: Meadows where grazing commenced after June 15th had a higher abundance of clouded Apollo butterflies than meadows where grazing commenced before June 15th.
[Statement 13]: Prescribed fire showed mixed effects on butterfly communities.
[Statement 14]: Some burned sites showed a higher abundance of heath fritillary adults, marsh fritillary caterpillar webs, and other species compared to unburned or grazed land.
[Statement 15]: The higher abundance of certain species on burned sites sometimes occurred after initial population reductions.
[Statement 16]: Some butterfly species had a lower abundance on burned sites compared to unburned land.
[Statement 17]: Prairie specialist butterflies were less abundant in burned prairies than in hayed prairies.
[Statement 18]: Generalist and migrant butterfly species were more abundant in burned areas than in hayed prairies.
[Statement 19]: Rotational burning generally showed positive effects on butterfly communities.
[Statement 20]: Sites managed by rotational burning every 2-5 years had a higher species richness of butterflies than unmanaged sites or sites managed by annual burning.
[Statement 21]: Under rotational burning management, butterfly abundance was higher on prairies burned more than one to four years ago compared to recently burned prairies.
[Statement 22]: Abandoning mowing showed variable effects on butterfly communities depending on the time since abandonment.
[Statement 23]: Grasslands abandoned for 3-13 years had a similar species richness of butterflies to annually mown grasslands.
[Statement 24]: Grasslands abandoned for more than 50 years had a lower species richness of butterflies than mown grasslands.
[Statement 25]: Some grasslands abandoned for more than 3 years had a higher abundance of butterflies than annually mown grasslands.
[Statement 26]: Some abandoned grasslands had a lower abundance of butterflies than annually mown grasslands.
[Statement 27]: The cessation of grazing showed patterns on butterfly communities similar to the cessation of mowing.
[Statement 28]: Grasslands where grazing was abandoned for more than 5 years had a similar species richness of butterflies to grazed grasslands.
[Statement 29]: The effects of ceasing grazing varied with time since abandonment.
[Statement 30]: Butterfly density was higher in grasslands where grazing ceased 2-9 years ago than in those abandoned for more than 10 years or those currently grazed.
[Statement 31]: Abandoned grasslands favored woodland and generalist butterfly species.
[Statement 32]: Grassland specialist butterfly species declined in abandoned grasslands.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the main alternatives to grazing for maintaining open grassland habitats, and how do their effects on butterfly communities compare?
